instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the prediction model for cassava tuber starch content in the related study for prediction of cassava tuber starch content and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the prediction model for cassava tuber starch content is the coefficient of determination (R2). The R2 value measures the proportion of the variance in the starch content that can be explained by the model. In the related study, the R2 value for the best calibration model developed using NIR spectra from selected wavelengths was 0.88. 

The R2 value can range from 0 to 1, with 1 indicating a perfect fit between the predicted and actual values. In this case, the R2 value of 0.88 suggests that the model can explain 88% of the variance in the starch content of cassava tubers. 

It is important to note that the R2 value alone does not provide a complete assessment of the model's performance. Other metrics such as root mean square error (RMSE) and residual predictive deviation (RPD) are also used to evaluate the accuracy and precision of the model. However, the extent to which the R2 value can go depends on the specific dataset and the complexity of the underlying relationship between the predictor variables (NIR spectra) and the response variable (starch content).

instruction: How were the selected significant wavelengths from both the Vis-NIR and Mid-NIR regions combined and used in the machine learning models for predicting the starch content in cassava tubers?
Output: The selected significant wavelengths from both the Vis-NIR and Mid-NIR regions were combined and used in the machine learning models for predicting the starch content in cassava tubers. The combination of wavelengths was done using machine learning techniques such as genetics algorithm (GA) and variables important projection (VIP). These techniques helped in selecting the most relevant and informative wavelengths from both regions. The combined selected wavelengths were then used to generate calibration models through machine learning algorithms, specifically support vector regression (SVR) in the related study. These models were used to predict the starch content in fresh cassava tubers based on the NIR spectra obtained from the selected wavelengths.

instruction: Can combining selected significant wavelengths from both the Vis-NIR and Mid-NIR regions using machine learning improve the prediction of starch content in cassava tubers?
Output: Yes, combining selected significant wavelengths from both the Vis-NIR and Mid-NIR regions using machine learning can improve the prediction of starch content in cassava tubers. The study mentioned in the text used genetic algorithm (GA) and variables important projection (VIP) to select significant wavelengths from both regions.
